snippet.textDisplay: Well, the Mac had a very good Firewire support, which was quite important to the creative people, who needed to connect their camcorders to their computers... Good Firewire support was also crucial to the audio creators and their equipment... and the Mac was said to have the best Firewire support, better than Windows or Linux, at least as far as their audio setups were concerned. Now Firewire itself has been more or less obsoleted by Thunderbolt, but Thunderbolt is no longer a reason to choose a Mac because Thunderbolt is neither as prominent, nor as essential, as Firewire once was... so a compelling reason to buy a Mac is no longer there.
snippet.textOriginal: Well, the Mac had a very good Firewire support, which was quite important to the creative people, who needed to connect their camcorders to their computers... Good Firewire support was also crucial to the audio creators and their equipment... and the Mac was said to have the best Firewire support, better than Windows or Linux, at least as far as their audio setups were concerned. Now Firewire itself has been more or less obsoleted by Thunderbolt, but Thunderbolt is no longer a reason to choose a Mac because Thunderbolt is neither as prominent, nor as essential, as Firewire once was... so a compelling reason to buy a Mac is no longer there.

snippet.textDisplay: Wait a second Linus, I gotta stop you for a second. At 7:08, according to that graph, the only difference between the Xeon W-3275, which costs $4500, and the Xeon W-3275M, which costs $7500, is support for more memory, which is a fact that you sort of breezed over. snippet.textDisplay:
What?! They are not focusing on audio engineers? Sorry thats just wrong. Yes the new Mac Pro is expensive, might be too expensive for most pp but its not targeted to consumer and even not for small business. Its also not about that some ppl are stuck on the Mac ecosystem because most professional user choose it without someone is forcing them and more important they have a reason. (For me its the better integration auf audio and midi into the OS what makes the workflow a lot easier for me.
Also have look into the world of the leading ppl from the industry and than ask yourself why they chose a Mac, specially when you mix some big Hollywood movies.
If you are on a low budget yes a Mac Pro is the wrong decision. If you are a big company who can afford it and, go for it its still one of the best workstations you can buy.

snippet.textDisplay:
"Apple actually are not the ones who marked this one up".

No. There is no way Apple pays anywhere near retail prices for their Intel cpus. They get a deep discount.

Also, the timing just was not right for Epyc 7002 (Rome). They started designing this several years ago, when it was only Epyc 7001. The 3647 socket Xeons have been around for years. While Epyc 7001 performed well in some cases, it wasn't enough for them to switch, so they would not have built this around first generation Epyc. Epyc Rome performs massively better than the first generation. Add the pci-express 4.0, and it starts to get hard to figure out why anyone would buy Xeon over Epyc or Threadripper. To take advantage of the pci express 4.0, they really needed new motherboards and such, so Rome wasn't an option for the release time frame of the new Mac Pro. Zen 3 based parts might be available in the right time frame for an upgraded model.

I wouldn't be surprised if Apple had systems running with AMD parts years ago, if only such that they can negotiate a better price from Intel. Intel doesn't seem to have anything in the pipeline that can compete with AMD parts literally for the next few years. The question is, how long can they wait to upgrade the Mac Pro to Epyc? If I bought an $6000+ dollar Mac Pro and Apple immediately came out with a 128 core / 256 thread Epyc based machine, I would be a bit unhappy. They probably have a lot of professional people who really want Epyc or Threadripper, so I expect that Apple has them running internally already. There is also probably a lot of Apple engineers who want Epyc. If regular users can make a hackintosh, then there is no way Apple isn't testing MacOS on AMD hardware internally.

I think there is a good chance that AMD based machines will happen. Apple may even be looking at AMD Ryzen 4000 mobile parts also. I would be temped by a Ryzen 4000 apu with a small HBM based gpu attached to it in a laptop. The intel cpu with an AMD gpu on the same package already exists. I don't think you will get Nvidia gpus though. AMD is going to release a big gpu at some point, so it may not be as much of a concern in the next year.
snippet.textOriginal:
"Apple actually are not the ones who marked this one up".

No.  There is no way Apple pays anywhere near retail prices for their Intel cpus.  They get a deep discount.

Also, the timing just was not right for Epyc 7002 (Rome).   They started designing this several years ago, when it was only Epyc 7001.  The 3647 socket Xeons have been around for years.  While Epyc 7001 performed well in some cases, it wasn't enough for them to switch, so they would not have built this around first generation Epyc.  Epyc Rome performs massively better than the first generation.  Add the pci-express 4.0, and it starts to get hard to figure out why anyone would buy Xeon over Epyc or Threadripper.  To take advantage of the pci express 4.0, they really needed new motherboards and such, so Rome wasn't an option for the release time frame of the new Mac Pro.  Zen 3 based parts might be available in the right time frame for an upgraded model.

I wouldn't be surprised if Apple had systems running with AMD parts years ago, if only such that they can negotiate a better price from Intel.  Intel doesn't seem to have anything in the pipeline that can compete with AMD parts literally for the next few years.  The question is, how long can they wait to upgrade the Mac Pro to Epyc?  If I bought an $6000+ dollar Mac Pro and Apple immediately came out with a 128 core / 256 thread Epyc based machine, I would be a bit unhappy.  They probably have a lot of professional people who really want Epyc or Threadripper, so I expect that Apple has them running internally already.  There is also probably a lot of Apple engineers who want Epyc.  If regular users can make a hackintosh, then there is no way Apple isn't testing MacOS on AMD hardware internally.

I think there is a good chance that AMD based machines will happen.  Apple may even be looking at AMD Ryzen 4000 mobile parts also.  I would be temped by a Ryzen 4000 apu with a small HBM based gpu attached to it in a laptop.  The intel cpu with an AMD gpu on the same package already exists.  I don't think you will get Nvidia gpus though.  AMD is going to release a big gpu at some point, so it may not be as much of a concern in the next year.

snippet.textDisplay:
I look at at all those Mac Pro prices at 9:27 and have to laugh when the Windows system noted below will SMOKE the Mac in performance!


AMD Ryzen Threadripper 2950x 16 core/32 thread CPU = $690.00
Asrock x399 Pro Gaming Motherboard = $444.00
Cougar RGB Full Tower Case = $220.00
Corsair 1000 Watt Power supply = $230.00
Corsair DDR4 RAM 128 Gigabytes = $590.00
XFX 5700XT 8 GB GPU card = $430.00
Samsung NVME Boot Drive 2 TB = $600.00
Four Samsung 4-TB Enterprise SSD drives (16 TB) = $2,600.00
Razer RGB Gaming Keyboard/Mouse Combo = $434.00
Corsair Wireless Carbon Gaming Headset = $100.00
Three Viewsonic 27 inch 2560 x 1440 1-ms displays = $1,569.00
Fixmax Massaging Ergonomic Gaming Chair XL-size = $165.00
Windows 10 Professional 64-bit OEM = $150.00
---------------------------------------------------------------
Total Cost: $8,222.00 U.S. (or $10,846 Canadian)

This is a system that will be SIGNIFICANTLY FASTER than
the Mac Pro (around $25,000 US) at its comparable
specification!

YES! 128 gigabytes of physical System RAM is a tad small these days but until AsRock updates it motherboard to bring it up to the 768 Gigabytes the chipset is actually capable of, you will have to make do with 128 gigabytes of physical RAM for a few months. If you're desperate for more memory, use a very large NVME drive with a big Virtual Memory scratch file letting Windows 10 create a 512 Gigabyte or One Terabyte Paging File. The NVME is so fast that it will FEEL like it's normal system RAM. And you can set the page file to ANY size you like at ANY TIME you like!

AND even the Gen2 Threadripper 2950x is so good, there is really no need to go up to a $2000+ CPU -- Save the money now and upgrade to a used cpu when the prices drop for the older 2990wx 32 core/64 threadripper next year!

In terms of BANG for the BUCK, this above system is the faaaaaar more cost-effective system to go for!

-

snippet.textDisplay:
In fairness to Apple, there's a zigzag-shaped gap between Intel and AMD's offerings. The Xeon W lineup has higher clock speeds and higher memory support, though at a ridiculous price point. AMD's EPYC lineup has all the memory support, but inferior clock speeds compared to Threadripper. The latter lacks registered and load-reduced memory support, which, given the industry's lack of support for unbuffered DIMMs larger than 32GB, places a memory limitation on that platform.


So if you want the best performance, you go with Threadripper. If you want massive memory capacity, you go with EPYC (4TB supported and realizable). If you want higher performance and large memory capacity, you need to go with Xeon W.


If I had to guess, AMD is going to close that gap in the near future, using a new workstation platform with basically everything EPYC has, but higher clock speeds. They'll have to charge similar prices, leaving the customer to decide whether higher performance or lower power consumption is more important. But that gap is still there today.


As for nVidia, Apple has legitimate reasons for shunning them, and they'd be foolish to expose themselves again to the same company run by the same man that did so much damage to them in the past.
snippet.textOriginal:
In fairness to Apple, there's a zigzag-shaped gap between Intel and AMD's offerings.  The Xeon W lineup has higher clock speeds and higher memory support, though at a ridiculous price point.  AMD's EPYC lineup has all the memory support, but inferior clock speeds compared to Threadripper.  The latter lacks registered and load-reduced memory support, which, given the industry's lack of support for unbuffered DIMMs larger than 32GB, places a memory limitation on that platform.


So if you want the best performance, you go with Threadripper.  If you want massive memory capacity, you go with EPYC (4TB supported and realizable).  If you want higher performance and large memory capacity, you need to go with Xeon W.


If I had to guess, AMD is going to close that gap in the near future, using a new workstation platform with basically everything EPYC has, but higher clock speeds.  They'll have to charge similar prices, leaving the customer to decide whether higher performance or lower power consumption is more important.  But that gap is still there today.


As for nVidia, Apple has legitimate reasons for shunning them, and they'd be foolish to expose themselves again to the same company run by the same man that did so much damage to them in the past.

snippet.textDisplay:
audio engineer here. although "audio" doesn't only mean music people, it's true that i see macs in every mixing studio ever. i dont like apple, but to be fair, mac has WAY better audio than windows. a lot of the hardware such as Avid's is simply designed for mac. there's also pro tools and eucontrol that, while they work on windows, are mostly designed for mac.
and stop running game benchmarks... NOBODY buys a mac for playing games, seriously.

but i literally had a mac pro 2013 spin the beach ball on me in the studio the other day. i wish i could influence the boomers in charge to buy AMD windows systems instead...

snippet.textDisplay:
Ridge Wallet does not offer World Wide Free Shipping.
Here is their response to my inquiry

"Hi Omar,

Unfortunately we are unable to offer our standard international shipping to certain countries because the local post office is not reliable enough, but we offer a 2-4 day UPS International option to the following countries: Algeria, Bulgaria, Chile, Colombia, Cyprus, Estonia, Kazakhstan, Lebanon, Malta, Namibia, New Caledonia, North Macedonia, Peru, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, Slovenia and South Africa
​
I apologize for this inconvenience. Please feel free to reach out with any other questions. "
snippet.textOriginal:
